Norm Centralized Acc. FL Acc.
GN 87.46±plus-or-minus\pm0.57 87.37±plus-or-minus\pm1.16

references:
In Table 5, we further apply FixBN to the experimental setting in Table 1 of FedTAN (Wang et al., 2023) to compare to other BN variants for FL. We note that FedTAN needs Θ​(3​L+1)Θ3𝐿1\Theta(3L+1) communication rounds linear to the numbers of BN layers L𝐿L, which is much more expensive than FixBN. HeteroFL (Diao et al., 2020) directly normalizes the activations, which cannot resolve the non-IID issue.
We note that FedBN (Li et al., 2021) was proposed for personalized FL, beyond the scope of this paper.

references: . It is well-known that increasing the number of local steps per round leads to greater drifts of the model from centralized learning

.
However, using more local steps also updates the local models more, potentially leading to an improved average model. To balance these competing considerations, we discuss two criteria. For
, more local steps mean fewer communication rounds, in which
, understandably, using more local steps improves both
, since more local SGD updates are made in total.

, we conduct a finer-grained analysis of the opposite trend. Starting from the same initial model, we vary the number of local SGD steps per round but fix the total SGD steps. We show the test accuracy of the (aggregated) global model as the training proceeds (x-axis).
Comparing
, we see a drastically different effect of
. In particular, while the performance of
seems unreasonably robust to training with fewer communication rounds but more local steps per round, suggesting the need for a deeper analysis of

We use 𝑺¯(T⋆)superscript¯𝑺superscript𝑇⋆\bar{\bm{S}}^{(T^{\star})} to approximate the global statistics because 𝑺¯(t)superscript¯𝑺𝑡\bar{\bm{S}}^{(t)} converges in the later rounds of FedAvg (see Figure 3 (a)). In terms of T⋆superscript𝑇⋆T^{\star}, we find it quite stable to be set at the middle round and fix it at 50%percent5050\% of the total FedAvg rounds throughout our experiments, unless stated otherwise.
FixBN is easy to apply, with no architecture and objective change and no extra training and communication costs. Please see Appendix C for the pseudo-code of FixBN.
